comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks State Records NSW for the large version - I can now see what everyone had for breakfast - Quaker Oats and Germea. It is terrific to be able to make out various familiar buildings from a birds eye view. The photographer I was thinking of is Melvin Vaniman who did a series of panoramas in 1904. I wonder if this photo is one of his? I think this is about that time - several Rocks areas are demolished post plague, and the 1904 Henry Bull building in Market Street is not evident - it would stick out like a sore thumb (see www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2414451497/ ).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
I was casually browsing through Max Kelly's 'Anchored in a Small Cove: A History and Archaeology of The Rocks, Sydney' (The Rocks : Sydney Cove Authority, 1997), and noticed that on p. 68. there is a portion of this photograph reproduced. The picture source is given as the Sydney Cove Authority (now the Sydney Harbour Foreshore Authority), and the date 1907 - the very circa date we ascertained.

Always pays to revisit the books on your shelf!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Hmm - puzzling over 1907 date, due to lack of 1904 Henry Bull building - see note and this - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/sydneystreets/then_&a...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Whoops! I'd placed my Whalers Arms demolition note on vacant land in Cambridge Street. Its now in its proper place ... with part of the wall still standing.

Hmmn ... got me puzzling now beachcomberaustralia. Did I read somewhere that the Henry Bull building was built in 1906? Would mean you could be correct with your note on the cranes on the horizon. I'm on the case ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: It appears from these newspaper reports of Henry Bull & Co. annual meetings for 1905, 1906, and 1907, that they were busy renovating their newly acquired building during 1905-1906 (including lifts - did they add extra floors?), and were happily operating from the premises in 1907. It is clear they were not operating from the building in 1904. My feeling is that our photo is not 1907 but much closer to the time of the demolition of the Whalers Arms in 1905 (hence that wall still standing), and during construction work on their new premises. The Sydney Morning Herald, Wednesday 20 December 1905, p. 11. The Sydney Morning Herald, Friday 21 December 1906, p. 9. The Sydney Morning Herald, Tuesday 24 December 1907, p. 9. I think the c.1904 Charles Kerry Pyrmont bridge photo is just that - circa. The Powerhouse has it c.1902-1917. Perhaps it should be bumped up to at least c.1906? Thoughts and pomegranates? ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
@ pelletheresearchexpert - that's a lot of Old Bull !

All these "c." dates are very confusing;   you are inclined to take them as gospel truth,  as I did from the City of Sydney website.  c.1906 sounds good for this photo, and I will re-examine the Pyrmont Bridge one.

James Barnet should have built a calendar on the GPO tower as well as the clock!

@ Jessica, what do you think?

comment.author: 7892196@N02
comment._content:
The big problem is correct attribution description and dating. Often authors (including big name historians) are careless about these things and the photos get copied in another work with the inaccurate date  and then another author picks the photo up and uses the wrong date and so the whole cycle goes on. For example there is a famous photo of a dust storm at Broken Hill where this has happened and their are duplicate photos with different captions and dates in various archives (which incidentally all claim copyright).

I think the Archives should add the reasons for the dating in the notes field so future users can understand how the decision was arrived at.

Iain

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/7892196@N02] You are quite right about the correct attribution and description. And we very much value the links verifying facts in the comments on our photostream. And your comment is very timely! We now have a new option in Photo Investigator (PI) which we will be experimenting with. It allows us to add notes, so where a lot of info has been added to an image here on Flickr we can link to it on PI. (If you click on the Digital ID Number in the description above you'll see what I mean) AB

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Next year is good; I have square eyes from staring at these photos. Is the Series 4481 completely digitized and online, or are there other glass negatives (?) lurking in the dungeons at State Records NSW? To recap - I think there are two panoramas taken months apart. The most complete panorama (including this photo) is - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... ? missing one - AUSN Co.Ltd building ? investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... (this photo) investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... ? missing one, possibly two, of Millers Point ? The other panorama is less complete - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... and investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... It would be wonderful to find the whole 360 degree view - panoramas were fairly popular at the time, but I do not recall seeing one ALL THE WAY AROUND ! There is also a 1905 birds-eye view interactive map which helps identify contemporary landmarks - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f115-sd&rgn=0.1...

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I think that beachcomberaustralia may have made the Flickr find of 2010. All very interesting information. A significant panoramist of the time was Melvin Vaniman, and the Sate Library of New South Wales holds a wonderful collection of his works. He was active in Sydney during 1903 and 1904, using a true panorama camera. Here's the master collection record at the SLNSW, with links to many digitised images NONE OF WHICH SEEM TO MATCH THE ONES ABOVE: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemdetailpaged.aspx?itemid=413018 Also on Flickr here: www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/sets/721576201782... and wikipedia here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melvin_Vaniman

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I know I should be tucked up in bed, but look what insomnia just led me to find ... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/6807372561/]from Millers Point: The Urban Village by Shirley Fitzgerald & Christopher Keating (Sydney: Hale & Iremonger, 1991), p. 45. I'm rather embarrassed I never noticed it before. The source is given as the Mitchell Library Special Picture File. Drumroll ... Ladies and gentlemen, without further ado, let me present the full panorama! The State Library of NSW holds 5 original copies of this panorama, attributed to Sydney Mail photographer George Bell. Taken from the top of the newly completed chimney of the Government Electric Light Co., it is dated 1904. This of course means the reference I found to the demolition of the Whalers Arms in 1905 (can't remember where) was incorrect - it must have been demolished at least a year earlier, and 1902 at the earliest. The "Mystery Sydney Panorama" turns out not to have been a mystery at all! D'oh! But of course this doesn't take away from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]'s *b r i l l i a n t* discovery of the scattered glass negatives. It would still be neat if State Records were able to find the remaining original glass negatives ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Whoopee!  This is Such Good News, and a great relief.  Great find and work, pellethepoet.  

A quick comparison reveals that George Bell's panorama uses the "Sydney" advert version on the Miles Building (ie <u>not this particular photo</u>),and other photos from "the other panorama" list above.  And one of the Dawes Point trees which is yet to be found.  No wonder Don Shearman's excellent attempts at reconstruction had gaps and inconsistencies - we were using pieces from two different jigsaw puzzles.   Now to find the rest of the pieces of both panoramas ...

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Taking a closer look at the first of your "Wildcards" I'm fairly sure that it is part of (1) of the George Bell panorama. The vessel moored at Walsh Bay just to the left of the warehouse appears to be the same as the one in the wildcard and the stern of the vessel at the extreme left of the Walsh Bay photo matches the stern of the 3 master in the missing fragment.
It looks to be the same vessel at the left of the warehouse in both panoramas, although the funnel is shorter in the Bell photo (and in the wildcard) than the other panorama. Perhaps she was in for a refit as there are obvious differences between the two photos for the next wharf to the right and the one at the extreme left suggesting a few days difference between the two sets.
If you flick quickly between the two photo (2)s there is a slight parallax difference as well, presumably caused by different height tripods. Might help identify the other wildcard as one of the two panoramas.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] 
...I've just been looking at a few microfilm reels...If you check out the Sydney Mail, 27 January, 1904, pp.224-225, you discover it includes a fascinating article titled 'Some Sydney Views: From a New Vantage Point'. It includes several pics which were evidently taken from the Dawes Point chimney...presumably not long before the article appeared...one of the pics is a ?version of pic 7, but taken maybe 30 seconds later...it shows the two ferries now abreast of each other...another pic appears to be the first of the wildcards indicated above...there are also two other pics which might/might not be missing pieces of puzzle...this Sydney Mail article is also interesting for the background it gives on how the photographers were hauled up the chimney! I can't work out how to link to the actual pages on Google News Archive...so if either of you guys can do this it would be great...maybe link the article to the individual pics as well if this is possible.

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: great stuff, atleast we know how high the photo was taken from, 200ft!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: These Sydney Mail pics thicken the plot a bit...for starters they require us to revise the date...well for some of the pics at least...just going on the Sydney Mail article you'd think the pics that appeared in the SM would have been taken in late 1903 or early 1904...then, the SM pic looking towards Blue's Point and McMahon's Point appears to have been taken on a different day to the other pics in the puzzle (above)...it's also odd how one pic turns up in the Sydney Mail where it is presented as the work of a SM photographer(s), whilst another pic taken from the same location 30 seconds or so earlier turns up in the T&CJ some 5 months later and is attributed to the Public Works Dept...should we believe what we read in the newspapers...was there more than one photographer...are we looking at same photographer same day...different photographers same day...same photographer different  days...different photographers different days?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] This wonderful Sydney Mail article of 27/01/1904 (see link above) names the three liners at East Circular Quay as (left to right) RMS 'China' (P&O), FMS 'Dunbea' (Messageries Maritimes), and the RMS 'Ormuz' (Orient Line).  The 'Dunbea' and 'Ormuz' were around Sydney in late January 1904,  but as far as I can work out from Trove, the 'China' was half way to England.    It may be a mistake ...  I was hoping to find a date when all three liners were at Circular Quay together (at 14:10 o'clock!).

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Those ships are a real puzzle!... ...and if you thought it was safe to go back into the water...well check this out...'More New Views of Sydney' from the SM 24/2/04...- news.google.com/newspapers?id=8mxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA... ; The pic on the second page appears to have been taken at about the same time as this one - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363510276/ I wonder whether the Powerhouse Museum or the Macleay Museum at Sydney Uni (which also has a collection of Kerry negatives) might have more Kerry & Co pics taken from the Dawes Point chimney...it would be odd if the PHM only had the one pic

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: That ship www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5352424755/in/pho... really does look like R.M.S. China...which per the shipping intelligence left Sydney on 12/12/1903 and arrived at Plymouth on 22/1/1904...I just wonder though...check out this pic of the China from the SLV - www.slv.vic.gov.au/pictoria/gid/slv-pic-aab62438/1/b20366 ; ...compare the funnels...the tops are slightly different...and that front mast is in a different location...maybe just minor modifications...note that the China underwent a major refit in ca. 1898-1900...it's possible that the SLV pic predates the refit...here's an 1897 sketch, again showing that front mast above the bridge... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article34571643 ; here's a pic taken in Sydney in 1902...again the slightly different funnels... - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71519882

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Good luck with trying to identify old ships! - it gets totally confusing with re-arranged rigging, shortened funnels, re-paints etc. Hence the over abundance of SS 'Orient' photos id'd by me on the PhM photos. An interesting red herring - Arthur Streeton painted "The Three Liners, Circular Quay" in 1893 (NGA), ten years before these photographs - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail-LRG.cfm?IRN=46595

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's a few pics of RMS China from the SLNSW...no dates of course - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=447623&...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Is it possible to get a higher resolution version of this pic? www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5352424755/ ...I'm trying to establish that this isn't RMS China and that the the reference to RMS China in the Sydney Mail report (above) must have been mistaken...which the shipping intelligence suggests.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: See new comments at pic 6 - the MOLDAVIA (?) and 7 (departure dates).  It seems all three ships were there between 27-30 January 1904.  Too tight a squeeze to get the photos into the Sydney Mail of 27/1/1901 ??  Hmmm ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That would be a back to the future squeeze! I think you meant "27/1/1904" :)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ha! Thank you - glad someone is paying attention.

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] has identified the ZIETEN as the nearest ship, at Circular Quay west from 17-30 Jan.  See pic 7 comments.  Discounting the MOLDAVIA gives us 19-30 January as possible dates.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Look what I saw over my Eggs Benedict this morning - - on the back page of the Sydney Morning Herald, Monday 25 June [eek!] February 2013. See also: blogs.smh.com.au/photographers/archives/2007/01/todays_ca... OBITUARY. MR. GEORGE BELL. The Sydney Morning Herald, Saturday 24 October 1925, p. 16. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16250579

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good find! Please send  me the Lottery results for the previous week in June 2013 !!
